size: Height: up to 3.3 m at the shoulder; Weight: 4,500-6,800 kg.
habitat: Once found throughout sub-Saharan Africa , the effects of poaching and habitat loss have caused the animal’s numbers and geographic range to decline to the point where conservation organizations have classified it as an endangered species .
funFact: The African bush elephant is considered one of Africa’s “Big Five” animals with which the continent is associated.

size: Length: 24-30 m; Weight: up to 180 metric tons.
habitat: The blue whale is found alone or in small groups in all oceans, but populations in the Southern Hemisphere are much larger.
funFact: Their hearts, which typically weigh about 180 kg (roughly 400 pounds), are the largest of any animal.

lifeExpectancy: 20 years in the wild and up to 30 years with expert care
habitat: Each animal confines its activities to a range of about 4 to 6 square km (1.5 to 2.3 square miles), but these home ranges often overlap substantially.
funFact: giant panda ,  ( Ailuropoda melanoleuca ),  bear with striking black-and-white coloration inhabiting bamboo forests in the mountains of central China .

size: Length: 2.7-3.1 m including tail; Weight: 180-260 kg for males.
habitat: The Bengal tiger’s appearance is distinguished from other tiger subspecies by its orange coat accented by prominent brownish-to-black stripes; a rare white-coated variant of the subspecies (the white tiger ) also exists.
funFact: While some 2,000–2,500 remain in the wild, several thousand more are thought to reside in zoos and private reserves around the world.

size: Length: 1.2-1.6 m; Weight: 30-50 kg depending on region.
habitat: The largest wolves are found in west-central Canada , Alaska , and across northern Asia .
funFact: It inhabits vast areas of the Northern Hemisphere.

size: Length: 2.4-3 m; Weight: 350-600 kg for males.
habitat: A polar bear is a great white northern bear (family Ursidae) found throughout the Arctic region.
funFact: Except for one subspecies of grizzly bear , the polar bear is the largest and most powerful carnivore on land.

size: Length: 60-85 cm; Weight: 4-15 kg depending on latitude.
habitat: Their habitats require the eucalyptus trees on which they feed and in which they live.
funFact: Koalas can live to about 15 years of age in the wild and somewhat longer in captivity.

size: Body length: 1.3-1.6 m; Weight: 55-90 kg for males.
habitat: This seems to be related to the storage of elastic strain energy in its tendons and muscles.
funFact: In addition, the heavy tail swings downward as…

size: Arm span: up to 2.0 m; Weight: 35-80 kg.

habitat: Rare battles may erupt when strange bulls invade territories in the mating season.
funFact: hippopotamus ,  ( Hippopotamus amphibius ),  amphibious African ungulate mammal .

size: Length: 1.7-2.5 m excluding tail; Weight: 150-250 kg for males.
habitat: Lions live in a variety of habitats but prefer grassland, savanna, dense scrub, and open woodland.
funFact: In captivity, they may live over 25 years.

habitat: Cheetahs inhabit a wide variety of habitats, including the dry, open country and grasslands where they are most often seen, as well as areas of denser vegetation and rocky upland terrain.
funFact: Nearly all the cheetahs remaining in the wild live in Africa.

size: Height: 1.4-1.8 m standing; Weight: 120-195 kg for adult males.
habitat: beringei beringei ), found in the montane rainforests and bamboo forests of the highland terrain north and east of Lake Kivu, near the borders of Uganda, Rwanda, and Congo (Kinshasa).
funFact: …the Congo (Kinshasa), and the mountain gorilla ( G.

habitat: Their wild prey has decreased as herding and ranching activities have expanded throughout their geographic range .
funFact: The snow leopard inhabits the mountains of central Asia and the Indian subcontinent , ranging from an elevation of about 1,800 metres (about 6,000 feet) in the winter to about 5,500 metres (18,000 feet) in the summer.

size: Length: 75-110 cm including tail; Weight: 3-8 kg.
habitat: Arctic fox ,  ( Vulpes lagopus ),  northern fox of the family Canidae , found throughout the Arctic region, usually on tundra or mountains near the sea.
funFact: As an adaptation to the climate, Arctic foxes have short rounded ears, a short muzzle, and fur-covered soles.

habitat: The platypus is found in terrain ranging from the high country of Tasmania and the Australian Alps to lowland areas close to the sea.
funFact: Adding to its distinctive appearance are conspicuous white patches of fur under the eyes.

habitat: The common bottlenose dolphin ( Tursiops truncatus ), which is the most widely recognized dolphin species, is found worldwide in warm and temperate seas.
funFact: It has also become the subject of scientific studies because of its intelligence and ability to…

habitat: tridactylus ) is found in northern South America; the maned sloth ( B.
funFact: The brown-throated three-toed sloth ( B.

size: Length: 1.8-2.4 m including tail; Weight: 30-50 kg.
habitat: Native to grasslands, savannas, and humid forests from Central to South America.
funFact: A giant anteater uses a two foot tongue that flicks 160 times per minute to lap up ants and termites.

lifeExpectancy: 15 years in the wild and up to 30 in care
habitat: Inhabits forest edges, heathlands, and alpine regions of southeastern Australia and Tasmania.
funFact: Wombats produce cube shaped droppings that stay put on logs and rocks to mark territory.

habitat: It hunts in packs of 15 to 60 or more and is found in parts of Africa south and east of the Sahara, particularly in grasslands.
funFact: The African wild dog is about 76–102 cm (30–41 inches) long, exclusive of its 31–41-cm tail, stands about 60 cm (24 inches) tall at the shoulder, and weighs about 16–23 kg (35–50 pounds).

size: Height: up to 2.1 m at the shoulder; Weight: 380-700 kg.
habitat: The largest moose specimens are found in Alaska and eastern Siberia; there bulls weigh 600 kg (1,300 pounds) and stand 2 metres (7 feet) tall at the shoulder.
funFact: The name moose is common in North America ; it is derived from the word moosh (“stripper and eater of bark”) in the Algonquian language of the Innu people of Quebec , Canada .

habitat: Much huntable land disappeared as industrial advance eliminated wildlife habitats and new farming methods reduced hedgerows and plowed under stubble soon after harvest,…
funFact: Both species were drastically reduced in numbers by hunting and now occupy small protected areas…

habitat: Meerkats live in cooperative packs of 3 to 25 with partially overlapping home ranges of a few square kilometres, which they mark with secretions of the anal glands.
funFact: The meerkat is slender and has a pointed little face, tiny ears, and black eye patches.

size: Length: 90-105 cm including tail; Weight: 3.5-8 kg.
habitat: In North America, black and silver coats are found, with a variable amount of white or white-banded hair occurring in a black coat, and these animals are sometimes called silver foxes .
funFact: It has the largest natural distribution of any land mammal except human beings.

size: Height: 1.5-2 m at the shoulder; Weight: 200-350 kg.
habitat: Found in the rainforests of the Congo region, the okapi was unknown to science until 1901, when British explorer Sir Harry Hamilton Johnston sent the first bits of hide to the British Museum .
funFact: However, British American explorer Sir Henry Morton Stanley had made the first report of the animal as early as 1890.

habitat: It also occurs around the Greater Antilles islands of the Caribbean
funFact: Today’s West Indian manatee has changed little compared with its ancestors of the past few million years.

habitat: gigantea , also classified as Smutsia gigantea ) of Africa, are terrestrial.
funFact: All are nocturnal and able to swim a little.

habitat: The Tasmanian devil is named for the Australian island-state of Tasmania , its only native habitat.
funFact: The coat is mainly black, and there is a whitish breast mark; sometimes the rump and sides are white-marked as well.

habitat: narwhal ,  ( Monodon monoceros ),  a small toothed whale found along coasts and in rivers throughout the Arctic .
funFact: Males possess a long straight tusk that projects forward from above the mouth.

habitat: The common clown fish is found on coral reefs in the tropical Pacific and Indian oceans from northwestern Australia , Southeast Asia , and Indonesia to Taiwan and Japan’s Ryukyu Islands .
funFact: The species achieved popular recognition through its depiction in the animated feature film Finding Nemo (2003).

habitat: White sharks have a complex circulatory system that conserves heat, and this heat is distributed throughout the body to warm its critical regions, giving the white shark a body temperature higher than the temperature of the surrounding water.
funFact: This adaptation is called regional endothermy, which is a type of warm-bloodedness.

size: Length: commonly 10-12 m; Weight: up to 20 tonnes.
habitat: Whale sharks are found in marine environments worldwide but mainly in tropical oceans .
funFact: whale shark ,  ( Rhincodon typus ),  gigantic but harmless shark (family Rhincodontidae) that is the largest living fish .

habitat: The members of the family are large-mouthed fish , deep-bodied but thin from side to side.
funFact: The John Dory ( Zenopsis conchifera ), a food fish of the Atlantic and Mediterranean, is one of the better-known species.

size: Length: 71-76 cm; Weight: 3.6-5.4 kg, larger in northern rivers.
lifeExpectancy: 4-6 years, with some surviving over a decade
habitat: Found on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean , it enters streams in the fall to spawn .
funFact: After spawning, adults are called kelts and may live to spawn again.

habitat: Native to Indo Pacific coral reefs but invasive across the western Atlantic and Caribbean.
funFact: A single lionfish can wipe out most juvenile fish on a reef thanks to its ambush hunting style.

size: Wingspan: 4-7 m; Weight: up to 1,350 kg.
habitat: Inhabit tropical and subtropical oceans, cruising between productive coastal and offshore waters.
funFact: Manta rays are known for leaping clear of the sea in spectacular flips and belly flops.

habitat: Seahorses are found in shallow coastal waters in latitudes from about 52° N to 45° S.
funFact: Their habitats include coral reefs , mangroves , sea grass beds, and estuaries .

habitat: Found in bays, estuaries, and coastal waters around Japan, Korea, and China.
funFact: Their organs contain tetrodotoxin so licensed chefs prepare fugu to avoid deadly poisoning.

habitat: The swordfish, an elongated, scaleless fish, has a tall dorsal fin, and a long sword , used in slashing at prey fishes, extends from its snout.
funFact: The sword is flat, rather than rounded as in marlins and other spear-nosed fishes, and has thus given rise to the name broadbill.

size: Length: 1.75-2.5 m; Weight: up to 20 kg.
habitat: …of this group is the electric eel ( Electrophorus electricus ).
funFact: The electrical organs, three on each side of the body, are derived from modified muscle tissue.

habitat: Between 1952 and 2000, about 200 specimens of Latimeria were caught on…
funFact: …1938 a living member ( Latimeria chalumnae ) was netted in the Indian Ocean near the southern coast of Africa.

size: Length: 1.8-2.5 m; Weight: up to 2,200 kg.
lifeExpectancy: At least 10 years in the wild
habitat: With the exception of the relatively deepwater Triacanthodidae and Triodontidae, the members of this order are usually found in waters less than about 65 metres (200 feet)…
funFact: …and the ocean sunfish ( Mola mola ), which may weigh over 900 kg (1 ton).

size: Length: 2-3 m; Weight: up to 200 kg.
habitat: The fish has a peculiar profile in that the front of the body is long and narrow, whereas the rear is flat and possesses only a rudimentary , rounded tail.
funFact: The pirarucu is a fish belonging to a primitive group of carnivorous bony-tongued fishes, the Osteoglossidae , that crush their prey with a large tongue studded with teeth.

habitat: The Siamese fighting fish, a native of Thailand , was domesticated there for use in contests.
funFact: Combat consists mainly of fin nipping and is accompanied by a display of extended gill covers, spread fins, and intensified colouring.

habitat: Generally, most percoid fishes fall within the range of 30 to 250…
funFact: Populations of red tuna ( Thunnus thynnus ) occur throughout the Mediterranean Sea and the eastern Atlantic.

habitat: Although captured sporadically worldwide, most specimens have been taken from deep marine waters near Japan.
funFact: The goblin shark can sling its jaws forward like a slingshot to snare prey in the darkness of the deep sea.

size: Length: up to 20 cm for females; males are dwarf-sized.
habitat: However, most anglerfish are about 30 centimeters (1 foot) long.
funFact: Deep-sea anglerfish can grow up to 1.2 meters (4 feet) in length.

habitat: It is an epipelagic species gliding above tropical and subtropical seas worldwide.
funFact: Glides of 200 metres or more let flying fish escape pursuing tuna and dolphins.

size: Length: commonly 61–76 cm; Weight: up to 40 kg in older individuals.
lifeExpectancy: Up to 25 years in cold northern waters
habitat: Historically, the term cod referred to Atlantic cod ( Gadus morhua ), a cold-water fish found on both sides of the North Atlantic .
funFact: In the present day, the term applies to all members of the genus Gadus ; however, it may be used colloquially to refer to select members of the order Perciformes .

habitat: A brightly coloured fish of lakes and swift streams, it is covered with small black spots and has a reddish band along either side.
funFact: The steelhead , an oceangoing form, is large and bluish and is also a prized game fish.

size: Length: 4-7 m; Weight: up to 1,000 kg.
habitat: The species is primarily found in the cold-water environments of the Arctic Ocean and North Atlantic, from Baffin Bay eastward to the Barents Sea , but its range also extends southward to the North Sea and the waters adjacent to the Eastern Seaboard of the United States .
funFact: Greenland shark ,  ( Somniosus microcephalus ),  member of the sleeper shark family Somniosidae (order Squaliformes, which also includes the dogfish family, Squalidae) also known for being the world’s longest-lived vertebrate .

size: Length: up to 2.5 m; Weight: 360 kg.
habitat: lanceolatus ) found in the Pacific and Indian ocean basins may reach 2.7 metres (8.8 feet) in length.
funFact: The adult is dull olive-brown with faint spots and bands.

size: Length: 2-3 m; Weight: up to 150 kg.
habitat: It is a long-bodied, scaleless fish , usually mottled greenish to blackish with a pale belly and dark fins.
funFact: It has a long anal fin, a small dorsal fin near the large, flattened head, and six mouth barbels, two of which, on the upper jaw, are very long.

habitat: Most perciforms are marine fishes, generally found along coastal areas of tropical and temperate regions of the world.
funFact: Perciforms are bony fishes that occur in abundance in both marine and freshwater areas of the world, ranging from shallow freshwater ponds to depths of more than 2,300 metres (7,500 feet) in the oceans.

size: Length: 1-2 m; Weight: up to 200 kg.
habitat: It has an elongated body, a protruding lower jaw , a rounded tail, and two dorsal fins.
funFact: niloticus was introduced into Lake Victoria in Africa, home to hundreds of cichlid fishes.

habitat: Roam warm surface waters of the Atlantic and Indo Pacific, often near strong currents.
funFact: Their speeds over 110 km per hour make them one of the fastest fish on the planet.

size: Length: 7-9 m; Weight: up to 5,200 kg.
habitat: Named for its habit of floating or slowly swimming at the surface, the basking shark is found predominantly in coastal areas in temperate regions of the Atlantic and Pacific oceans .
funFact: basking shark ,  ( Cetorhinus maximus ),  huge, slow-swimming shark of the family Cetorhinidae.

size: Length: up to 2.3 m; Weight: 190 kg.
habitat: Wrasses are found throughout the world in tropical and temperate seas.
funFact: Most species are elongated and relatively slender.

habitat: The development of an anadromous life cycle—that is, spawning in fresh water but migrating to the sea for feeding and maturation—has allowed species of trout and salmon to extend their range greatly,…

habitat: Axolotl populations have declined considerably due to a combination of habitat loss (largely driven by Mexico City’s continued urbanization), water pollution , and invasive species (such as carp and tilapia , which compete with axolotls for food and prey upon them).
funFact: The name axolotl is also applied to any full-grown larva of Ambystoma tigrinum (tiger salamander) that has not yet lost its external gills.

lifeExpectancy: 4-6 years in the wild; longer in care
habitat: Poison frogs, or dendrobatids, are small and range from 12 to 19 mm (0.5 to 0.75 inch) from snout to vent in the minute poison frogs ( Minyobates ) to about 65 mm (2.6 inches) in the skunk frog ( Aromobates nocturnus ).
funFact: Poison frogs inhabit the forests of the New World tropics from Nicaragua to Peru and Brazil , and a few species are used by South American tribes to coat the tips of darts and arrows.

habitat: They are found primarily in the New World tropics but are also present in Europe , Australia , and across much of nontropical Asia .
funFact: Of these, the hylid, or “true,” tree frogs from the family Hylidae are the most numerous.

habitat: Favors damp deciduous forests and springs across central and southern Europe.
funFact: Bright yellow blotches warn predators that the salamander secretes toxic skin alkaloids.

size: Length: 10-15 cm; large females can exceed 20 cm.
habitat: This toxic species is native to South and Central America but is now found across the world, from Australia and Oceania to Caribbean islands and parts of the United States , after being introduced as a natural pesticide on sugarcane plantations.
funFact: cane toad ,  ( Rhinella marina ),  a large terrestrial omnivorous amphibian considered to be one of the most invasive pests on Earth.

habitat: Salamandrids range from moderately slender to robust-bodied forms.
funFact: The family is divided informally into newts and “true salamanders” (that is, all non-newt species within Salamandridae regardless of genus).

habitat: It is found in the Black River system of Arkansas and Missouri .
funFact: The hellbender is typically coloured brownish gray with black spots.

size: Length: 1.2-1.8 m; Weight: up to 50 kg.
habitat: The diversity of animal life is perhaps greatest in the ranges and valleys of Tibet and Sichuan, the latter province being renowned as the home of the giant panda.

habitat: They cling to leaves above forest streams in Costa Rica, Panama, and Colombia.
funFact: Males guard egg clutches on leaf undersides until tadpoles drop into streams below.

habitat: Axolotl populations have declined considerably due to a combination of habitat loss (largely driven by Mexico City’s continued urbanization), water pollution , and invasive species (such as carp and tilapia , which compete with axolotls for food and prey upon them).
funFact: The name axolotl is also applied to any full-grown larva of Ambystoma tigrinum (tiger salamander) that has not yet lost its external gills.

habitat: Occupy cold lakes, ponds, and slow rivers across eastern North America.
funFact: They keep feathery external gills their entire lives instead of completing metamorphosis.

habitat: As an aquatic cave dweller, the olm has lost its skin pigmentation , and its vestigial but light-sensitive eyes are covered with skin.
funFact: It retains numerous larval traits, such as well-developed gills , a lateral line system , and tiny limbs.

habitat: It has a flat, squarish body, small eyes, and a flat head with loose flaps of skin on the snout and jaws.
funFact: The digits end in small, star-shaped appendages that aid food finding.

habitat: It is valuable for mosquito control, because it eats the eggs and young of those insects.
funFact: laevis was introduced to the United States and Britain.…

habitat: The largest species grow about 30 cm (12 inches) long.
funFact: Frogfishes, members of the group known as anglerfishes, are usually provided with a “fishing pole,” tipped with a fleshy “bait,” located on the snout and derived from the first dorsal fin spine.

habitat: Males of the Central American dendrobatid Colostethus inguinalis have…
funFact: …female strawberry poison frog ( Dendrobates pumilio ; see arrow-poison frog) uses a different strategy to protect her young.

habitat: Darwin’s frog is unique among amphibians for its brooding habits.
funFact: Males pick up eggs about to hatch and carry the developing young about in their distensible vocal pouch until they are able to fend for themselves.

size: Length: 8–10 cm, excluding the long toes.
lifeExpectancy: Estimated at around 6–8 years in the wild
habitat: They dwell high in the rainforest canopy of Borneo and peninsular Malaysia.
funFact: Huge webbed feet let them glide 15 metres between trees when escaping danger.

size: Body length: up to 32 cm; Weight: 3.3 kg.
habitat: The main threats to the goliath frog, which is an endangered species, include habitat loss due to logging and farming, hunting , water pollution , and being part of the illegal wildlife trade.
funFact: It is the world’s largest living frog species.

habitat: Poison frogs, or dendrobatids, are small and range from 12 to 19 mm (0.5 to 0.75 inch) from snout to vent in the minute poison frogs ( Minyobates ) to about 65 mm (2.6 inches) in the skunk frog ( Aromobates nocturnus ).
funFact: Poison frogs inhabit the forests of the New World tropics from Nicaragua to Peru and Brazil , and a few species are used by South American tribes to coat the tips of darts and arrows.

habitat: They are predominantly terrestrial and live in thick herbaceous vegetation and low shrubbery.
funFact: They are not as adept at climbing as are most other hylids.

habitat: Outside of the breeding season, when it may be found in ephemeral woodland ponds, it is seldom seen.
funFact: The spring peeper, with its high, whistling call, is one of the first frogs to vocalize and breed in spring.

habitat: The following classification, which is based on their toxic effects, has been found to be useful: (1) plants that are poisonous to eat, (2) plants that are poisonous upon contact, (3) plants that produce photosensitization, and (4) plants that produce airborne allergies (see Table 6).
funFact: Several systems have been devised for the classification of poisonous plants, none of which is completely satisfactory.

habitat: Burrows through moist soils in South American forests, gardens, and plantations.
funFact: Skin secretions discourage predators, and mothers feed hatchlings with outer skin layers.

habitat: In many seeing animals , including humans, it is required for vision in dim light and is located in the retina of the eye —specifically, within the tightly packed disks that make up the outer segment of the retina’s photoreceptive rod cells , which are specially adapted for vision under low-light conditions.
funFact: Rhodopsin was discovered in 1876 by German physiologist Franz Christian Boll, who observed that the normally reddish purple frog retina turned pale in bright light.

habitat: The Panamanian golden toad’s skin contains a potent water-soluble toxin called zetekitoxin, which affects nerve cells and protects the toad from most predators.
funFact: However, if minor precautions are taken, these toads can be safely handled.

habitat: bufo ) are representative, are stout-bodied with short legs that limit them to the characteristic walking or hopping gait.
funFact: The thick, dry, often warty skin on the back is generally…

habitat: Lives in woodlands, swamps, and backyard trees across eastern North America.
funFact: They can shift from bright green to mottled gray in hours to match tree bark.

habitat: It is a cool-climate species that occurs from the northeastern quarter of the United States and throughout most of Canada to central and southern Alaska.
funFact: The wood frog is tan to brown with a distinctly dark facial mask.

habitat: On the ventral, flexor aspect of the pectoral limb, the pectoralis is found in all tetrapods.
funFact: The limbs of urodeles are quite weak and tend to be carried forward passively with the undulations of the body.

habitat: However, in 2021 the IUCN decided to list the Komodo dragon as an endangered species because climate models suggested that between 30 and 70 percent of the species’ habitat would be lost by 2040 to increases in sea level .
funFact: The dragon is a monitor lizard of the family Varanidae.

habitat: It has the proportionately largest head of the sea turtles; this feature may be an adaptation that…
funFact: Green sea turtles prefer marine grasses but, if these are not available, will eat algae.

habitat: Occupy forests, bamboo thickets, and mangroves from India through Southeast Asia.
funFact: Unlike most snakes, females build and guard nests for their eggs.

habitat: It grows to about 50 cm (about 20 inches), is stout-bodied with black and pink blotches or bands, and has beadlike scales.
funFact: A closely related species, the Mexican beaded lizard ( H.

habitat: Although there are reports of population declines in some areas, such decreases are localized, since most populations are found in protected areas or in areas not frequented by people.
funFact: The Nile crocodile is the largest crocodile in Africa and one of the largest living reptiles , some individuals rivaling the estuarine (or saltwater) crocodile ( C.

habitat: Inhabit volcanic highlands and arid lowlands across the Galapagos Islands.
funFact: Each island hosts tortoises with unique shell shapes adapted to local vegetation.

habitat: The heart consists of four chambers arranged in a linear sequence.
funFact: Before the origin of lungs , the vertebrate circulatory system had a single circuit: in the fishes , blood flows from heart to gills to body and back to the heart.

habitat: The leatherback sea turtle lives in the world’s temperate and tropical oceans , from the high seas to intertidal habitats.
funFact: leatherback sea turtle ,  ( Dermochelys coriacea ), species of sea turtle notable because it lacks scales and a hard shell.

habitat: The alligator’s geographic range extends from the Mexican states of Coahuila , Nuevo León , and Tamaulipas northeastward to Oklahoma and Arkansas and eastward through the Gulf Coast to North Carolina , South Carolina , Georgia , and Florida .
funFact: The species is one of two classified in the genus Alligator , the other being the Chinese alligator ( A.

habitat: The scaly membrane around its neck is used as a large part of the lizard ’s defensive posture.
funFact: Normally, the neck frill , often as wide as the lizard is long, lies like a cape over the shoulders.

habitat: Two species occur in Asia; one is native to southern India and Sri Lanka ( Chamaeleo zeylanicus ), and the other (the European chameleon, C.
funFact: chameleon ,  (family Chamaeleonidae),  any of a group of primarily arboreal (tree-dwelling) Old World lizards best known for their ability to change body colour .

habitat: Terrestrial pythons are regularly found near water and are proficient swimmers, but they hunt and eat almost exclusively on land.
funFact: Most pythons are terrestrial to semiarboreal, and a few, such as the green tree python ( Morelia viridis ) of Australia and New Guinea , are strongly arboreal.

habitat: Its typical habitats are brushy flatlands and slopes, rock ledges, high river banks, and junk piles on the edges of towns and cities .
funFact: western diamondback rattlesnake ,  ( Crotalus atrox ),  a large, venomous, aggressive, and highly dangerous pit viper inhabiting arid and semiarid scrublands in North America from southern California east to western Arkansas in the U.S.

habitat: Iguanids are found throughout the Americas from southern Canada to the tip of South America .
funFact: The only exceptions are one genus ( Brachylophus ) in Fiji and other Pacific islands and two genera ( Oplurus and Chalarodon ) in Madagascar.

habitat: This harmless reptile is extremely difficult to find in its natural habitat, partly because of its cryptic coloration and morphology and partly because it remains perfectly still when approached.
funFact: The shape of its body and many of its habits are similar to those of horned lizards of North America , which are in the family Iguanidae.

habitat: Its range is wide, from Argentina to northern Mexico.
funFact: Though it thrives in tropical rainforests, it also inhabits savannas, cane fields, and semiarid scrublands.

size: Length: 5-6 m; Weight: up to 250 kg.
habitat: Found in swamps, slow rivers, and flooded forests of the Amazon and Orinoco basins.
funFact: As ambush predators they sense prey vibrations with pressure sensitive pits on the snout.

size: Length: 70-120 cm; Weight: up to 12 kg.
habitat: Endemic to rocky shorelines of the Galapagos Islands where cold currents upwell.
funFact: They sneeze out salt to purge the seawater ingested while grazing underwater algae.

habitat: Occupy tropical forests and human dwellings across Southeast Asia and the Pacific.
funFact: Their loud two syllable ?to-kay? call is the source of the species name.

habitat: Some tortoises rarely see water, while other turtles spend virtually their entire lives in it, be it in a single small pond or traveling the vast open ocean .
funFact: There are more than 350 species of turtles.

size: Shell length: 40-80 cm; Weight: up to 80 kg.
habitat: Although native populations are found exclusively in the United States , from Texas east to Georgia and Florida and from Illinois and Kansas south to the Gulf Coast , non-native populations are found in various other states and in South Africa , where it is considered an invasive species .
funFact: alligator snapping turtle ,  ( Macrochelys temminckii ), species of freshwater turtle in the family Chelydridae .

habitat: It lives in sub-Saharan Africa and is one of the continent’s most dangerous snakes.
funFact: The average black mamba is 2–2.5 metres (6.6–8.2 feet) long, with a maximum length of 4.3 metres (14 feet).

habitat: Prefer moist forests, meadows, and marsh edges in the eastern United States.
funFact: A hinged plastron lets them close their shell so tightly even predators cannot pry it open.

habitat: The usual habitat is desert or semidesert sandy country.
funFact: They inhabit western North America from British Columbia southward to Guatemala and from Arkansas and Kansas westward to the Pacific coast.

funFact: freshwater crocodile ,  ( Crocodylus johnsoni ),  moderately large species of crocodile inhabiting inland swamps , rivers , and other tropical freshwater environments in the northern parts of Queensland , Western Australia , and Australia’s Northern Territory .

funFact: The stout body is boldly patterned with rectangles and triangles of buff, purple, and brown, which gives the snake its velvetlike appearance.

habitat: Live in desert scrub and rocky foothills of the Mojave and Sonoran deserts.
funFact: They spend most of the year in burrows to escape heat and conserve moisture.

habitat: They are found in Africa south of the Sahara, through southern and southeastern Asia , in Australia , and on islands in the southwestern Pacific.

size: Length: 3-5 m; Weight: up to 90 kg.
habitat: The snake’s wide distribution in mainland Southeast Asia and Indonesia and the establishment of a population numbering at least several tens of thousands in the Everglades and other parts of southern Florida conceal severe population crashes of up to 80 percent in a single decade in some parts of its native geographic range .
funFact: In addition, the Burmese python has established populations in southern Florida , where it is considered to be an invasive species .

habitat: Inhabit tropical oceans worldwide and nest on sandy beaches during mass arribadas.
funFact: Tens of thousands of females may crawl ashore together during a single nesting event.

habitat: After World War II the peregrine falcon suffered a precipitous population decline throughout most of its global range.
funFact: The peregrine falcon is best known for its diving speed during flight —which can reach more than 300 km (186 miles) per hour—making it not only the world’s fastest bird but also the world’s fastest animal .

habitat: Adults are coloured black and white with areas of orange and yellow on the head, neck, and breast.
funFact: The species gathers together into approximately 50 colonies that settle on ice shelves and landfast ice along the coastline of Antarctica .

habitat: Found in lowland rainforests from southern Mexico through the Amazon basin.

lifeExpectancy: 7 years in the wild; longer in captivity
habitat: The blue jay is found in coniferous and deciduous forests east of the Rocky Mountains in both the United States and southern Canada .
funFact: It is an intelligent, adaptable species related to crows and ravens , and it has learned to coexist with people , living in cities and suburban residential areas, where it is infamous for its aggressive behavior at bird feeders.

habitat: Gruiforms are an ancient group with a rich fossil history, but many families are now restricted in range and few in number.
funFact: Members of the order occur on every continent, but the only family with worldwide distribution is the Rallidae ( rails , gallinules , and coots ), with 138 living species .

funFact: Adapted to desert and forest, the species migrates only when food is scarce.

habitat: Most of the harpy eagle population can be found in the Amazon Basin in South America ; however, the species can also be found in pockets of habitat throughout Central America and northern South America south to Colombia’s Pacific coast to northwestern Venezuela .
